150851160.review:
"The Forest" is a captivating and intense survival game that plunges players into a mysterious and hostile open-world environment. Developed by Endnight Games, this title delivers a unique blend of horror, crafting, and exploration that keeps players on the edge of their seats throughout the entire experience.

One of the standout features of "The Forest" is its atmospheric and visually stunning world. The game's graphics are impressive, with lush forests, dynamic weather, and hauntingly beautiful landscapes that create an immersive and believable setting. The attention to detail is commendable, from the realistic day-night cycle to the eerie sounds of the forest that add to the overall sense of dread.

The game's narrative begins with a plane crash, leaving the protagonist stranded on a mysterious island inhabited by cannibalistic mutants. The storyline is minimalistic but intriguing, encouraging players to explore and uncover the island's secrets at their own pace. The open-world design allows for non-linear gameplay, providing a sense of freedom in choosing how to approach survival.

Survival in "The Forest" requires careful resource management and crafting. Gathering materials, building shelters, and creating weapons are essential for fending off the aggressive mutant inhabitants. The crafting system is intuitive, although it may take some time for newcomers to grasp the mechanics fully.

The horror element in "The Forest" is palpable. The mutants' unpredictable behavior and the game's dark, claustrophobic caves create a tense atmosphere. The first-person perspective intensifies the scares, making encounters with mutants genuinely frightening. However, it's worth noting that the horror aspect may not be suitable for everyone, as some players may find it too intense.

Multiplayer adds another layer to the experience, allowing friends to join forces in the struggle for survival. Cooperation becomes crucial when facing the island's challenges, and the shared sense of accomplishment enhances the overall enjoyment of the game.

Despite its strengths, "The Forest" isn't without its flaws. The learning curve for survival mechanics might be steep for some players, and occasional bugs and glitches can detract from the immersion. However, regular updates from the developers have addressed many issues, showcasing their commitment to improving the overall gaming experience.

In conclusion, "The Forest" is a gripping survival game that successfully blends horror and exploration. Its atmospheric world, engaging crafting system, and multiplayer capabilities make it a standout title in the genre. While not without some imperfections, the overall experience is well worth the investment for those seeking a thrilling and challenging adventure in the heart of a mysterious and dangerous forest.

The Forest is not a game for the faint of heart. It is dark, challenging, and sometimes downright disturbing. But for those who are looking for a truly immersive and unforgettable experience, The Forest is an essential title.

150384233.review:
WOW! What an amazing blend of the survival-horror genres!  Especially your first couple nights can be heart-rate spiking and dread filled experiences as you huddle around a fire to stay warm and only venture into the darkness for small necessary supplies.  Over the course of the game you get to gather resources and build up a place you can feel safe in to do tasks at night which feels rewarding and fun.   There is ample space to explore and spread venture out during daytime hours.  

Unfortunately there are some ISSUES:
First, resource gathering can be a bit of a grind-especially when your ability to carry things back to your base is severely limited by the amount you can carry in inventory.  
Second, on 'hard' difficulty, which is always my preference, the enemies are unrealistically difficult even when you have more upgrades weapons.  Some fights involve cornering the enemy and smacking them 15 or so times before they finally collapse. This gets old really quick-especially when those enemies re-spawn when you leave an area and return.  I'd recommend doing  normal difficulty to hopefully avoid this problem. 
Finally, what is MOST frustrating for me is the occasionally glitchy building mechanic. The game will allow you to set down a blueprint for a structure in places you can't access to build. This issue-combined with the inability to delete a blueprint unless it is reachable to interact with, means you can quickly get your UI cluttered with "you need more sticks!" notes and flags denoting pending construction projects that never go away.  Breaks immersion quite a bit and the only resources is to quit game and load last save, sometimes putting you back hours. 

BOTTOM LINE: Great game for people who love mysteries/survival/open world/horror genres.  With a few intentional moves it is worth it: Save frequently, don't building a blueprint unless it is fully visible, play on normal difficulty, and be less ambitious with your builds.

150376242.review:
After surviving a plane crash, I found myself in a forest. I didn't know where I was, but I knew I had to find food and shelter. That's when a game of cat and mouse began. I had no idea who they were or what they wanted. Clearly they weren't here to help. So what was it? Unfortunately, I didn't take long for me to find out and my struggle for survival got even more intense...

The AI of the enemies is something I've never experienced before in a video game. I mentioned a cat and mouse game and this is why you'll never rest easy. It's unpredictable. You have to learn the 'rules' of a nightmarish society that make no sense and, on top of that, have no qualms in breaking their own rules whenever they feel like it. Good luck with that. Countless times I jumped off of cliffs or into waters, exposing myself to nature's predators, just to escape the deranged figures stalking me.

I will say the crafting system took me a bit to figure out. You have a survival manual that shows you what and how to craft, but it doesn't tell you anything about what they are or how to use them. Obviously, a cabin and a campfire are very straightforward. But there are certain structures that are vague and even quite challenging to build, especially if you want to build them in the 'correct' spot. In time, you'll figure it out and it will become more enjoyable. Another gripe I have [spoiler]is that you can only officially end the game by being a horrible person and I disliked that, because even though it's a horror game, I still want to be the 'hero', doing 'the right thing'.[/spoiler] However, I suppose I can somewhat 'excuse' it and blame it on your deteriorating sanity. I mean, let's be honest, it's hard to stay sane with everything you see and go through in this game.

So besides the minor criticism, yes, this game is extremely unsettling and horrific. The darkness, the sounds... I'm genuinely scared when I play this game. At times, it's a claustrophobic nightmare. I hate and love it at the same time. It's a game that makes me want to crawl under the covers and pretend I don't exist.

150183282.review:
Do you like Survival games where you craft things? How about horror games that can still take you by surprise every now and then even after playing for hours? Well then this game is for you. The game takes mechanics from both of these genres to give you an unsettling, yet fun experience in one game. Build a base and defend it from mutant cannibals that roam the island, explore caves to find items to make your life easier, and solve the mysterys of the peninsula.

Plus, this game has an actual storyline for you to complete. The main character, Eric LeBlanc's plane crashes on the island and his son Timmy is kidnapped by a mysterious man covered in red paint. You'll need to explore caves to find key items to help you in your search for Timmy and get to the bottom of the sinkhole in the center of the island.

Don't wanna defend your base from the mutants that roam the map? Well good news is there's a difficulty setting you can pick called "Peaceful" This makes it to where no mutants appear on the surface and will only appear in caves. I can't recommend this mode personally because it takes a chunk out of the gameplay experience. But if you're looking for a mode where you can build stuff anywhere uninterrupted, this might be a good option.

150158912.review:
Las principales causas de la guerra de Malvinas fueron las siguientes:

La usurpación de las Malvinas por Gran Bretaña en 1833. La Argentina había tomado posesión efectiva de las islas en 1820, mediante la designación de un gobernador y el envío una guarnición militar. Luego de la usurpación, el gobierno del primer ministro Charles Grey declaró las islas como parte del Imperio británico.

La decisión de las Naciones Unidas de tratar el caso de las islas Malvinas en el marco del Comité de Descolonización. Desde 1945 hubo varias resoluciones de la ONU que consideraron a las Malvinas, las Sandwich y las Georgias del Sur como territorios en litigio.
La «crisis de los chatarreros», como se llamó al incidente protagonizado por 41 trabajadores argentinos contratados para desmantelar instalaciones balleneras abandonadas en las islas Georgias del Sur. El 19 de marzo, los chatarreros izaron la bandera argentina, lo que provocó la reacción de Gran Bretaña, que envío dos buques para obligar a los operarios a arriar la bandera.
La decisión del presidente de facto argentino, Leopoldo Fortunato Galtieri, de invadir las islas para ganar popularidad y perpetuar en el poder a la última dictadura militar.
La férrea postura de la primera ministra británica Margaret Thatcher de no aceptar la pérdida de las islas y de utilizar el conflicto para fortalecer su gobierno, que estaba debilitado por la oposición de los sindicatos y parte de la población a su política de reformas neoliberales.
El apoyo dado por el presidente de los Estados Unidos, Ronald Reagan, a la decisión de Gran Bretaña de recuperar las islas. Además de amigos personales, Reagan y Thatcher eran los dos grandes líderes conservadores de principios de la década de 1980.
Lo erróneos que resultaron los dos supuestos sobre los que Galtieri y la Junta Militar decidieron el intento de recuperación de las islas Malvinas: que el Reino Unido limitaría su reacción al terreno diplomático y que los Estados Unidos no permitirían una escalada militar del conflicto.

You chop down trees and gather sticks. You set rabbit traps. You can make new tools. But that's about it. I've had root canals that have been more fun. The base-building interface is awful. In fact, most of the interface mechanics are awful. You can't run more than a minute, but you can shoulder-carry 2 large logs. Water is hard to find, because it's difficult to line the 'drink' cursor up with the water properly. The first shelter you build looks like a trap Coyote set for Roadrunner. While you bumble through this boring mess of a game, you're constantly harassed by HP Lovecraft people. But even that's boring! Seriously, I don't see the appeal of this unmitigated disaster pretending to be a video game. I should have spent the money on something more useful, like investing in a hedgehog farm. This game is about as fun as a DIY colonoscopy. Stay away. I didn't, and now I hate myself.

149952579.review:
As a single player game (didn't try multiplayer) it's pretty good. Not quite Subnautica, but if that's why you're looking at it, it's definitely in the right space. 

The good 
- the island (forest) looks great, and it's a pretty good map that gives you lots to explore. I spent a lot of time happily roaming the landscape, seeing what was there.
- base building is a lot of fun, even if you're fairly casual about it. I didn't go overboard but had a coastal stockade, a houseboat on a scenic lake, and island getaway and several hunting camps by the end.
- the cannibals are very well done, quite believable in their behaviour. I was actually enjoyed watching them. was intrigued figuring out what they were doing and felt bad (sometimes) about initiating hostilities.
- the story (told through things you find) is actually pretty intriguing. Still not quite sure about all of it, but there was definitely more to it than I was expecting. 

The bad
- while it's got a good middle, the beginning was steep (I got smacked by a cannibal the moment I stepped off the plane first run) and the end dragged (long, long level to explore, few enemies, and no save points)
- it's pretty unintuitive for a survival game - I died second run because I assumed you could drink from springs, streams, rivers.... No, you drink pond water. Or, um, need turtles.
- the interface is clunky as hell. Even at the end I was constantly going for a left click where (this time) it should have been a right click. It took me forever to figure some stuff out (resetting traps I'm looking at you).
- once you piss off the cannibals, it can get to a point where you can't move without them coming after you. Makes building that next base hard. Luckily there's vegetarian mode.

I got a good 60 hours out of it, did all the caves, both endings, and played around briefly after I'd finished it. I'm not sure there's much of a post game - it got old quickly - but I might give it a replay at some point or try multiplayer. Either way, on sale - I think I got it for £3.80 or something - it was worth it.

Worth noting, I didn't use a walkthrough but I did use a map of the island and, in particular of the cave network. I honestly don't think I'd have found half of them without it. People saying they "beat" the game in like 5 hours are either the luckiest people in the world or, yeah, slavishly following a walkthrough. Even with a map, you need to explore alot.

149863421.review:
Once upon a time, there was an island with a forest. But not for long, since a plane crashes onto it and our protagonist, who survives the crash, starts to search for his son Timmy, who also was on the plane. Instead of fairies, this forest contains cannibals and mutants, who want to do harm to the protagonist. But with the help of a book on survival and with a lot of will, he will start to explore caves and the surface, find loot, craft, find dead passengers and trying to avoid any kind of confrontations with the cannibals. This game seems to be designed for people with a lot of looting skills, who are not afraid to defend themselves against the occasional mob trying to either kill him or capture him - seems to be random, which one occurs. Runs quite stable on WIN11, although it occasionally crashes. But frequent saving in the same place where you sleep prevents any greater loss of advance.
Only once trouble occurred, when trying to find the location of the final battle. But also the weaknesses of the enemies were never completely discovered in a blind playthrough, except for melee or shooting arrows, which works on everyone.
This game is meant for more than one playthrough (and even has to be played in multiplayer) to get all the achievements, but it is also great to play it in single player mode.  Recommended.

149849450.review:
As much as I love Valheim, Subnautica, Raft (etc.) this one didn't work for me.  The story is cool, universe ok, building ok. 

Combat is atrocious, nothing connects, feedback is poor, mobs are stupidly fast and resilient, and at the same time dumb and cheezable, which is the way most people seem to be managing them from looking at youtube. I wonder if the game wouldn't actually be better in story mode.  There should certainly be a "easy" where canibals are present but die easier.

The game is also tedious. Cave darkness should be fun but it's actually not. The light tools (lighter and flashlight) are weak an ineffective. Climbing ropes takes forever, Cutting tree is fluky and annoying, carrying capacity is initially too low. So many games have done survival right, this isn't one of them.

But for me I think the worse part was that the game never gives you time to breath.  You are supposed to be building a base, but you need to constantly (and I mean constantly) deal with food and drink. There's no logical progression, no on boarding. You need skins of all types right off the bat to craft very basic bags. So you run around chasing all that stuff, only to get attacked over and over by cannibals. You never have time to settle in, master your environment, explore, etc.  It's fight and feed always all the time.  In the end, you 'explore' by dying, and going somewhere else the next game. You do that enough, and you finally get a sense of the world.

Level design is also rough all over. Caves with passages that don't look passable, and vice versa, underwater paths with no foreshadowing, sprawling caves that all look the same and offer very little land marking, etc.  I've had to google a few times because I was stumped, which almost never happens. "Oh yeah, there's a hidden interactive passageway at the bottom of the lake at the bottom, swim down and hit X, you'll see." =D

Anyway, I see why people like it, there's lots to like, it's hardcore, it's visceral, it's gory. I just didn't enjoy my time with it.

149845053.review:
Se que Walter White dice que no deberias probar tu propia mercancia pero los desarrolladores de este juego cuando lo terminaron tubieron que haber dicho'' joder si esto fuera droga me lo meteria hasta por la raja'' y tienen toda la razon debido que a  lo largo de de la serie  Walter White, interpretado magistralmente por Bryan Cranston, es diagnosticado con cáncer terminal. Con su vida en juego y la preocupación por el bienestar financiero de su familia, Walter toma una decisión drástica y entra en el peligroso mundo de la fabricación y distribución de metanfetaminas. Su compañero en este viaje turbio es Jesse Pinkman, interpretado por Aaron Paul, un antiguo estudiante y traficante de poca monta.

Lo que comienza como una necesidad desesperada se convierte en una espiral descendente de moralidad cuestionable. A medida que Walter y Jesse se sumergen más en el oscuro submundo del narcotráfico, la serie explora temas complejos como la ética, las consecuencias de las decisiones y la dualidad de la naturaleza humana.

La transformación de Walter White es el corazón de la serie. De un hombre aparentemente inofensivo, enfrentándose a las dificultades financieras y de salud, se convierte en "Heisenberg", un alias que adopta para ocultar su verdadera identidad mientras se embarca en una carrera peligrosa para producir la mejor metanfetamina del mercado. Este cambio radical es visualmente simbolizado por la metamorfosis de su apariencia física y la evolución de su mentalidad.

La relación entre Walter y Jesse es otro aspecto central de la trama. A medida que trabajan juntos, la dinámica entre el profesor y el estudiante evoluciona, pasando de una relación puramente comercial a una conexión más compleja y emocional. A lo largo de las temporadas, los lazos que los unen se ponen a prueba repetidamente, enfrentándolos a dilemas éticos y emocionales.

El conflicto con otros narcotraficantes, representados por personajes memorables como Gustavo Fring y Tuco Salamanca, añade capas adicionales de tensión a la narrativa. La DEA, encabezada por el cuñado de Walter, Hank Schrader, también está en la búsqueda de los culpables, lo que complica aún más la situación. Los giros y vueltas inesperados mantienen a los espectadores al borde de sus asientos, mientras la tensión aumenta con cada episodio.

El impacto de "Breaking Bad" va más allá de su trama intensa. La serie es conocida por su cinematografía excepcional, escritura inteligente y personajes complejos y bien desarrollados. La atención meticulosa a los detalles, desde la elección de la música hasta la simbología visual, contribuye a la riqueza y profundidad de la experiencia de visualización.

Bryan Cranston y Aaron Paul ofrecen actuaciones que son aclamadas por la crítica y el público. Cranston, en particular, recibió múltiples premios Emmy por su interpretación de Walter White. Su habilidad para retratar la complejidad del personaje, desde la vulnerabilidad hasta la crueldad, es una parte fundamental del éxito de la serie.

La conclusión de "Breaking Bad" es tan impactante como su inicio. Sin entrar en detalles para evitar spoilers, el final es una obra maestra en sí misma, cerrando magistralmente los arcos de los personajes y proporcionando un cierre satisfactorio a la historia.

En resumen, "Breaking Bad" es una serie que va más allá de ser entretenimiento televisivo. Es una exploración profunda de la moralidad humana, las consecuencias de nuestras acciones y la complejidad de las relaciones interpersonales. Con una narrativa magistral, actuaciones destacadas y una ejecución técnica impecable, la serie se ha ganado su lugar como una de las mejores de la televisión contemporánea, dejando un impacto duradero en la cultura popular y en la forma en que se cuentan las historias en el medio televisivo, ahora teniendo todo esto en cuenta e llegado a la conclucion de que si, los desarrolladores deberian probar su mercancia.

This game should be called "The Cave" or "The Walking" or something else.

I can't measure my disappointment on this game. I wish i would never touched it and it will lay inside my library forever.

First, pros:
- Multiplayer - fun
- Maybe story
- Monster design

Then, cons:
- Any gameplay mechanic has no worth. Absolute. Any. Survival element is pity - you have very huge amount of resources, combat is awful, stealth - useless, AI - dumb and etc.
- WALKING, holy hell walking. Walking in caves, walking outside, travelling between story points has ENORMOUS amount of walking. Tired of walking? Good for you! We have scuba diving. Diving in caves. Then walking, again. Repeat.
- Caves. Caves are dark, lighting system is broken, lighter = torch = firecamp. No difference. 
- Almost no content. "Unique" items in most cases are useless. Even upgrade system don't save it. Because what? Upgrading is also useless.
- Collectibles (photos, treasure cards). Good luck finding a spot between rock and tree. It's pretty obvious, sure.

Overall game has so much in it and none of them are connected with each other. One gameplay decision totally ruins another. Gameplay features conflicts between themselves. None of mechanics are made to finished state. Bad to play, awful to deal with it. 

Completing this game literally did brain damage to me. Holy Gods repair my neuron connections, it hurts so much.

149603681.review:
Save your precious IRL hours. Don't waste your time on this game. There is a BIG save game flaw/bug/misinterpretation of what to click - situation with this game.

Quick Backstory:
I was initially excited about this game. I setup a dedicated server, had my friends buy it, we all logged on and had a blast the first night. THEN... the next night we logged on and everything we did the night before was gone! Inventory, weapons, building... everything just gone.

Dedicated Server:
I leave all my dedicated servers running 24/7. The dedicated server is still set to the default option to save the session every 30 minutes, so it wasn't a manually 'Save World' problem. Since there is no 'Host' player and we are all just 'Client' players, everyone can quit when then like. So nothing should have gone wrong.

Clients:
As many posts and forums on this exact same 'Save game issue' state to do, we all saved our characters before quitting for the night. The next day, we all clicked on 'Continue' and not 'Join' to start the next session. Only to find the world was completely restored as if we never played the game before. We didn't have to watch the intro cut scene again, we just loaded up into a fresh world in front of the plane.

Menu Confusion:
Although I learned ahead of time and told all my buddies how to avoid the problem, the menu system in this game is confusing as far as reconnecting to a server to 'Continue' the game you previous played. When you start the game and choose 'Multiplayer' from the menu, you have to click 'Join Server' and then look up the server in the list. After this, you want to avoid any other button that says 'Join'. Once you find the server in the list, you are presented with 2 options: 'Continue' or 'Join'. This leads to confusion because it should say: 'Continue' or 'Start New Game'. Clicking on 'Join' does NOT load your saved character and continue where you left off. Clicking 'Join' starts you off fresh in the world with no inventory, no no buildings, and you get to watch the opening cut-scene again. This would have been an easy fix for the developers to simply change the word 'Join' to 'New Game'.

Troubleshooting:
Just for the sake of sanity, I restored a backup and I restarted the dedicated server several times. Sometimes the buildings would show back up. Randomly some of our inventory came back when we reconnected to the server after restarting it. However, we never got all of our stuff back.

A Fair Second Chance:
We decided maybe it was a glitch so we pressed on with the new world and again played for a couple hours. We all saved our characters (some at a tent and others at structures we built). We logged off for the night and hopped back on the next day. Again, the dedicated server is always running 24/7 so it should have saved the session automatically. But the exact same thing happened. We all started up to a fresh world and none of our stuff.

Call to Uninstall and Refund:
With a consistent pattern and what amounts to around 5-6 hours of wasted IRL time... we made the call to uninstall and see if we could get a refund. The answer to the refund by Steam... Nope! You played the game over 2 hours and it's been more than 48 hours since purchase so no refund will be issued.

Steam's Refund Policy:
We understand that if this was a single player situation, sure, don't refund us. But how were we supposed to know within 2 hours that the game has this 'Saving game' glitch? We thought maybe something was up on our side so we did some troubleshooting to confirm it was the game and not us. We didn't even get to progress in the game because nothing was saved and we had to rebuild. But whatever, we all got the game on sale for $4.99 so it's not a terrible loss. Just frustrating.

Summary:
I can't speak to the Single Player game because we all got this for the Multiplayer aspect. If you're thinking about multiplayer though, find a different game. The developers moved on to their new game "Sons of the Forest" so they will probably never fix this particular 'Save Game' issue. A side note on the new game: multiple forums are complaining about the Save Game feature in that game also being flawed. So we are more than likely skipping that one altogether.

I know this was long, but I hope this helps a few people save their money and get something else.

149543271.review:
After beating the game, all I can say is...
Oh my god, what a gaming experience. Can't say enough good things about this game; constant high alert, constant strategy implementation, and constant tactical awareness. You also have the creative edge of manipulating your surroundings to your advantage as well. These cannibals are vicious, and don't even get me started on the creepy mutants... Having building destruction on is a nightmare, and on Hard mode, it makes for an amazing gaming experience. I love the feeling of immersion, constant impending doom, and the reward of making a split-second decision.

As for the gameplay itself, if you do things correctly (which you'll figure out quickly with each failed attempt, so save frequently) the game rewards you graciously. If you mess up, you'll get punished pretty hard; but not SO hard that you feel like quitting (mainly just gotta fetch your belongings from the spot you died, which is likely still pretty hostile, so just be on high alert). Once you get into the flow of the game and beat it on Normal, try it again on the Harder modes with disadvantaged gameplay settings; your strategy will end up changing real quickly ;) good luck.

This game is perhaps most fun and enjoyable in multiplayer. But, if you love the horror of being alone and actively pursued with no help, then go singleplayer. So in conclusion, this game does an amazing job, no matter which direction you're looking to play.

149496624.review:
Have I played this game enough?  No, only three hours. However, my biggest recommendation right now is: Do not play Valheim first.  Valheim has a much better build system, quick slots for selecting items, a map(!), and it doesn't have a book that you're constantly flipping through dozen of tabs to find something to make.

Graphics are decent, although changing display settings like night-time visibility doesn't seem to work. But that could be due to using Proton under Linux. The enemy AI is definitely challenging as they will lure you in and then kill you.

I do find the delay between when you click to swing your weapon and when it happens to be annoying.  But then I'm use to that "working" as expected in games like Valheim and 7 Days to Die.

Meat spoiling because you've held on to too long is a new on me.  Annoying, but now that I know...

My final grip at this point is actually having to build a shelter in order to create a location where you manually have to select to save the game.  Really?  Why make this this so difficult?  Why make it an issue at all?  I guess it's a quality-of-life issue that I have with this game over other survival games that I've played.

The Forest Review Score: 9 out of 10

Pros:

Immersive open world
Deep survival mechanics
Terrifying cannibals
Engaging co-op multiplayer
Constant updates and new content
Cons:

Can be difficult for solo players
Some technical issues
Ending could be more fleshed out
Overall:
The Forest is an outstanding survival horror game with a deep and rewarding gameplay loop. The open world is immersive and unforgiving, the survival mechanics are challenging and satisfying, and the cannibals are some of the most terrifying enemies in video games. The co-op multiplayer is also a blast, allowing you and your friends to work together to survive and build a base.

One of the things that makes The Forest so special is its commitment to realism. The survival mechanics are very detailed and require you to carefully manage your resources and needs. For example, you need to eat, drink, and sleep regularly, and you also need to build shelter to protect yourself from the elements and the cannibals.

The cannibals themselves are also very well-designed. They are intelligent and resourceful, and they will often hunt in packs. They are also very good at blending in with their surroundings, making them difficult to spot.

The Forest also features a robust co-op multiplayer mode. You can play with up to eight other players, and you can work together to build a base, explore the world, and fight off the cannibals. The co-op multiplayer adds a whole new dimension to the game, and it is a lot of fun to play with friends.

The Forest is still under development, but the developers have been very active in adding new content and fixing bugs. The game has received several major updates since its release, and it continues to get better all the time.

Recommendation:
The Forest is a must-play for fans of survival horror games. It is a challenging and rewarding experience that will keep you coming back for more. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a deep and immersive survival game.

Specifically:

The Forest's open world is one of its greatest assets. It is large, diverse, and full of secrets to discover.
The survival mechanics are deep and rewarding. You need to carefully manage your resources and needs in order to survive.
The cannibals are terrifying enemies that will keep you on your toes.
The co-op multiplayer is a lot of fun and adds a whole new dimension to the game.
The developers are very active in adding new content and fixing bugs.
Overall, The Forest is an outstanding survival horror game that I highly recommend to anyone looking for a deep and immersive experience.

149267021.review:
THE FOREST

Sobrevivir en un lugar inquietantemente tranquilo y amenazador con el objetivo de
encontrar a tu hijo raptado por criaturas desconocidas.
Juego de recolección, exploración y crafteo el cual podrás compartir con amigos
dentro de un mismo servidor, para poder resolver el misterio de la isla. Para esto
tendrás que obtener alimentos y bebidas, para llenar tus necesidades básicas.
También tendrás que dedicar tiempo a cocinar y explorar bien el territorio en busca de
valiosos recursos, actividades que nos ayudarán a afrontar con garantías los
exigentes retos.
Con los recursos y materiales obtenidos podrás fabricar estructuras, defensas y
elementos decorativos para tu fortaleza, en la cual podrás estar refugiado y poder
sobrevivir los días que te tome escapar.
Los terribles acontecimientos de la trama principal, se irán descubriendo mediante
obtención de objetos repartidos tanto en la superficie como en las cuevas que irás
explorando. Sin ninguna duda, el planteamiento jugable y narrativo es increíble,
permitiéndonos descubrir poco a poco todo lo que ofrece el territorio y sembrando de
dudas y misterios un hábitat hostil.
The Forest llega también a Playstation con una adaptación muy buena que no cambia
la esencia principal, logrando poder disfrutar la experiencia de terror que mezcla muy
acertadamente supervivencia, crafting y exploración dentro de un enorme mundo
abierto. Aunque el paso de los años hace que ciertas mecánicas estén anticuadas, de
igual forma lo disfrutarás volviéndose una oportunidad imprescindible para aquellos
que no lo hayan disfrutado todavía.

Developers: Endnight Games
Publishers: Endnight Games
Release Date: 30 de Abril, 2018
Platforms: PC y PS4
Nota: 7/10

The Forest is a great game (with an even greater command cheat system) that was fun with friends up until me and a friend loaded a save which caused my items (roughly 5 hours worth of work) to be deleted back to a much earlier save (with multiple saves in-between which was weird) while his were completely up to date. We tried reloading, searched up similar issues but to no avail; and therefore used hacks to get my stuff back to how it was and continue on from there.
If you have no idea what you're doing don't fret, this game is really simple to understand and will make future play-through's much more enjoyable and quicker in my experience.
My only tip would be that even though it doesn't seem to be of use, make sure everyone saves including non-host members in multiplayer games - it would seem that's where my issue stems from although we're not too sure.
Other than that small bug, the game was very funny with some particularly memorable bugs.

149245954.review:
Poner la harina cernida en la mesa y hacer un hoyo al medio, formando una corona. Espolvorear la Sal de Mar Gourmet por los bordes externos de la corona. En un bol pequeño, mezclar la levadura con el azúcar y un poco de agua tibia (2 cucharadas aproximadamente, adicional a la de los ingredientes)  y revolver hasta disolver bien. Poner la mezcla de levadura en el centro de la corona y de a poco ir formando la masa del centro hacia fuera, usando los dedos para integrar todos los ingredientes y formar la masa. Agregar más agua, la manteca y formar una masa lisa y blanda.
Porcionar la masa en pedazos chicos y ovillar (formar bolitas lisas). Poner los ovillos en una lata levemente engrasada con aceite y aplastar levemente. Tapar con una bolsa o alusaplast  y dejar fermentar por unos 10 minutos. Volver a aplastar la masa y pinchar con un tenedor 2 a 3 veces. Leudar (dejar que suba el pan)hasta que doble su volumen, alrededor de 45 minutos, en un lugar que esté tibio.
Hornear a 220ºC por 15 minutos o hasta que los panes estén levemente dorados.

A fun co-op survival game with a little bit of horror thrown in. Co-op is definitely more fun than single player but it is a little buggy in places, mainly to do with achievements but it doesn't really impact the enjoyment of the game.

Seems to work really well over the internet with only the occasional lag when a cave system loads in.

I paid £3.87 for the game which is an absolute bargain for the size of game, so would recommend if you enjoy the survival genre and have friends to co-op with.

[/spoiler] The crafting is also good, well-thought for the idea of being completely autonomous and self-relying in a situation with no other other humans [spoiler] (well, at least normal humans) [/spoiler] to lean on for survival; which reminds me very much of Kenshi, [spoiler] another game that also incidentally has a part of the map called “Cannibalia” where the cannibals look pretty similar to the ones from this game; and I like that aesthetic (despite Kenshi's a game that I overall struggle to enjoy).
